abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Natural Resources
            Development Project for Albania were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory; Global Environment Objective (GEO)
            outcome were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            substantial; risk to GEO outcome was substantial; Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory and borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: natural resource management projects are
            most difficult to monitor and, to be effective; any system
            needs to be as simple and easily used by non-Information
            Systems (IT) specialists as possible. In a project like
            this, by which the management plan is such an important part
            of project implementation, standardized digital mapping is
            essential in this day and age of Geographic Information
            Systems (GIS). The mandated annual environmental audit
            report did have well defined and clear terms of reference.
            Local stakeholder involvement was necessary for receiving
            feedback on local site conditions and other commune-specific issues.

            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF053325-PHRD-ALBANIA: COMMUNITY-BASED

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Natural Resources Development
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Natural Resources
            Development Project for Albania is to establish and maintain
            sustainable, community-based natural resource management in
            about 218 communes in upland, and mountainous erosion-prone
            lands. The extension is necessary to: (i) help the local
            governments finalize the preparation of forest and pasture
            management plans and implement the investments to improve
            forest and pasture lands; and (ii) assist the Government to
            implement the institutional forestry reform in central,
            regional and local level through staff training,
            institutional and legal advice. The Borrower has a written
            action plan to complete the implementation of the project
            during the extension. Disbursement of project funds until
            August 31, 2010 reached US$ 13,444,193 while another US$
            4,000,000 has already been committed, out of the total donor
            financing of US$ 17,200,000. Agreement which was amended to
            extend from November 1, 2010 until November 1, 2011.

display_title.display_title:
Albania - Natural Resources
            Development Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF053325-PHRD-ALBANIA: COMMUNITY-BASED

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about the
            Albania Natural Resources Development Project. Forests cover
            more than 50 percent of Albania’s surface area. Following
            roughly two decades of transition, illegal logging, and
            overgrazing of forests and pasture lands, Albanians living
            in rural areas started to become conscious of the damaging
            effects these practices were having on the environment.
            Participatory planning and management of forest and pasture
            lands was piloted in 30 communes during the implementation
            of the Albanian Forestry Project financed by the World Bank
            in 1996. Given its positive outcome and wide community
            support, the approach was extended under the National
            Resource Development Project in more than 200 communes. This
            experience led to the decision of the government of Albania
            in June 2008 to formalize forest land rights transfers to
            345 communes, resources which are used by almost one million
            people. The project had addressed the issues of soil
            degradation and improved watersheds. More sustainable,
            community-based natural resource management in Albania will
            lead to enhanced productivity, incomes, and, overall,
            improvements in land and water resources for the public
            sector. The investments have helped to support increases in
            income earned from forest and agricultural activities in
            communal areas and a significant reduction in erosion, and
            Albania is one of the first countries to sequester carbon on
            eroded lands through the BioCarbon Fund.
